interview.question: Not unexpected given how well you've been playing. She's a seeded player. You have to be pretty pleased.
interview.answer: Yeah, very happy. You know, thought I played pretty well; happy with how the day went.

interview.question: What was the key for you today?
interview.answer: I think serving. My serving definitely helped me today. You know, in the first set when I got down Love‑40 when I was up 4‑2, I think being able to hold and come back definitely helped me out.

interview.question: Do you feel different in this slam versus the other ones you've played in the past?
interview.answer: I feel more prepared for this one. My first US Open main draw, it was a big stadium and wasn't really used to it. But I feel good about this one so far, yeah.

interview.question: What are the differences in terms of when you're on the court and how that manifests itself?
interview.answer: I think it's kind of in everything. You know, worked really hard this off‑season. Think I'm in pretty good shape. Working with a new coach. It's been going really well. Hopefully I can keep it up.

interview.question: I don't know if you saw Lindsay Davenport tweeted today that she hadn't had hope for a young American like you since Serena Williams. How does that make you feel to get that kind of compliment?
interview.answer: I mean, it makes me happy. You know, I think I've been working really hard. I think it's starting to show.

interview.question: No nerves at all. Have you felt any real nerves going on court?
interview.answer: First round here was a little bit nerve‑wracking. But I think today it was much better just having that one match under my belt. You know, I was playing an Australian, big court, crowd was against me, but I felt like today I just played tennis.

interview.question: When you were 14, you had that win in Ponte Vedra, and then you were at the French Open, the wild card, and you had a stomach muscle pull. How long did that take you out? Took a while to heal, didn't it?
interview.answer: I don't really remember, honestly.

interview.question: You have Kerber next round, a top‑five player. A little bit different approach or just go out and try to rip it?
interview.answer: I mean, I think just really have to focus on playing my game and just worrying about me. She's obviously a good player. She's been around and she's done well the last couple years. I think if I just focus on what I'm doing, then it doesn't really matter.

interview.question: So both your parents are lawyers, right?
interview.answer: Yes.

interview.question: Both still working?
interview.answer: Both are still working, yes.

interview.question: How did you get from lawyers' kid, especially two working lawyers, to become a tennis player at this level?
interview.answer: Complete luck. No one in my family plays tennis. I just came upon it one day. Just thought, Hey, I'll try it. You know, it's worked out pretty well.

interview.question: So you got addicted pretty quickly?
interview.answer: For sure. Right away.

interview.question: First time?
interview.answer: First time, fell in love.

interview.question: Went home and said, I got to play tennis every day; get me lessons?
interview.answer: Every single day. My parents fed me balls. Eventually it turned into having a coach, and then it went to being at an academy.

interview.question: Your parents don't play?
interview.answer: Neither one can play tennis.

interview.question: What initially attracted you when you saw tennis for the first time?
interview.answer: The outfits (smiling). Really wanted a tennis dress. My parents told me that if I played, they would buy me one. I was like, Hey, I'll try it.

interview.question: Who were your tennis idols growing up? Who did you like to watch?
interview.answer: Really, really liked watching Kim Clijsters. I thought she was very passionate, and I thought her movement was incredible.

interview.question: How old were you when you started, picked up the racquet for the first time?
interview.answer: I was four.

interview.question: How much of the transition, adjustment, I mean, you switched from Chris to the USTA, but it's on the same property. Was there a big adjustment or...
interview.answer: I mean, there wasn't a huge adjustment. I mean, it's the same place, same courts, just different coach. Working with someone different.

interview.question: Do your parents watch you play? Are they watching on TV now?
interview.answer: Yes, they are. My mom is in Illinois right now working. My dad is in Florida with my little sisters.

interview.question: They're watching you online?
interview.answer: Yes, they both watched me.

interview.question: Do they get nervous?
interview.answer: My mom doesn't really get nervous. And I don't think my dad gets very nervous either.

interview.question: Any chance they're going to come over if you advance a little bit further?
interview.answer: Probably not. I think I'm here by myself. But I always tell them that they have to come like maybe next year.
